translated: But in the Sankhya system, it is subsidiary to the discrimination of the universal Self. This is the direction.

analyzed: nanu yathā ukta viveka khyātitaḥ pi atyantam avidyā ucchedaḥ na ghaṭate
translated: Now, even from the manifestation of discrimination as described, the complete cessation of ignorance does not occur.

analyzed: viveka khyāteḥ avidyā pratibandhaka tva mātra tvena viveka khyāti nāśa uttaram punar abhimāna sambhavāt
translated: Because, the manifestation of discrimination being merely a hindrance to ignorance, the sense of ego can arise again after the destruction of the manifestation of discrimination.

analyzed: śukti rajata viveka darśinaḥ pi kāla antare śuktau rajata bhrama vat iti
translated: Even for one who has seen the distinction between a shell and silver, there is the illusion of silver in the shell after some time.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta vaiṣamyāt
translated: Because of the inequality of the example.

original: śuktyādiṣu jāte 'pi sākṣātkāre dūratvādirūpaviṣayadoṣāṇāṃ paṭalādirūpakaraṇadoṣāṇāṃ cotpattisambhavena punarbhramo yuktaḥ /
analyzed: śukti ādiṣu jāte sākṣātkāre dūra tva ādi rūpa viṣaya doṣāṇām paṭala ādi rūpa karaṇa doṣāṇām ca utpatti sambhavena punar bhramaḥ yuktaḥ
translated: In the case of a shell etc., even though the knowledge has arisen, the illusion is proper due to the possibility of the arising of the defects of the object in the form of distance etc. and the defects of the instrument in the form of cataracts etc.

original: anātmanyātmābhimāne tvanādivāsanaiva doṣaḥ sarvāstikasammataḥ jātamātrasyābhimāne doṣāntarānupalabdheḥ /
analyzed: anātmani ātma abhimāne tu anādi vāsanā eva doṣaḥ sarva āstika sammataḥ jāta mātrasya abhimāne doṣa antara anupalabdheḥ
translated: But in the case of the superimposition of the self on the non-self, the only defect is the beginningless impression, which is accepted by all theists, because no other defect is perceived in the superimposition of one just born.

analyzed: sā mithyājñāna vāsanā yadā viveka khyāti paramparā janya dṛḍha vāsanā unmūlitā tadā eva viveka sākṣātkāra niṣṭhā ucyate
translated: That false knowledge impression is uprooted by the strong impression generated by the series of the knowledge of discrimination, then alone is said to be the culmination of the knowledge of discrimination.

original: tatpūrvamavaśyaṃ vāsanāleśato mithyāṃśasya kasyāpyātmani bhāvāt tasyāṃ ca vivekakhyātiniṣṭhāyāṃ jātāyāṃ na punarabhimānaḥ sambhavati vāsanākhyadoṣābhāvāditi
analyzed: tat pūrvam avaśyam vāsanā leśataḥ mithyā aṃśasya kasya api ātmani bhāvāt tasyām ca viveka khyāti niṣṭhāyām jātāyām na punar abhimānaḥ sambhavati vāsanā ākhya doṣa abhāvāt iti
translated: Before that, because of the existence of some part of the false in the self due to the part of the impression, and when that culmination of the knowledge of discrimination has arisen, the superimposition does not occur again due to the absence of the defect called impression.

analyzed: tu mahat vaiṣamyam
translated: This is a great inequality.

original: yadi tu buddhipuruṣayoranyonyapratibimbanādikamavivekakāraṇaṃ doṣa iṣyate tadā tu
analyzed: yadi tu buddhi puruṣayoḥ anyonya pratibimbana ādikam aviveka kāraṇam doṣaḥ iṣyate tadā tu
translated: But if the defect that is the cause of non-discrimination is accepted to be the mutual reflection of the intellect and the self etc., then

original: taddoṣaṃ bādhitvaiva vivekasākṣātkāra udita iti na tasya punarbhramahetutvaṃ phalabalena
analyzed: tad doṣam bādhitvā eva viveka sākṣātkāraḥ uditaḥ iti na tasya punar bhrama hetu tvam phala balena
translated: The realization of discrimination arises even by overcoming that defect, so it cannot again be the cause of delusion by the power of the result.

analyzed: yoga ja dharma a sahakṛtasya eva tasya doṣa tva kalpanā asambhavāt iti
translated: Because it is not possible to imagine that defect to be associated only with the yoga-born dharma.

analyzed: viveka khyāti niṣṭhā ca gīta ādiṣu lakṣitā
translated: And the culmination of the realization of discrimination is seen in the Gita and other texts.

original: prakāśaṃ ca pravṛttiṃ ca mohameva ca pāṇḍava /
analyzed: prakāśam ca pravṛttim ca moham eva ca pāṇḍava
translated: Light, activity, and delusion itself, O son of Pandu,

original: na dveṣṭi sampravṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati //
analyzed: na dveṣṭi sampravṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati
translated: he does not hate when they occur, nor does he desire them when they cease.

analyzed: udāsīna vat āsīnaḥ guṇaiḥ yaḥ na vicālyate
translated: Sitting as if indifferent, unshaken by the gunas,

analyzed: sarva ārambha parityāgī guṇa atītaḥ saḥ ucyate
translated: he who has renounced all undertakings, he is said to have transcended the gunas.

analyzed: iti guṇa atītaḥ nivṛtta guṇa abhimānaḥ
translated: One who has transcended the gunas is one who has ceased to identify with the gunas.

analyzed: adhikam tu jñāni lakṣaṇam agre vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: But we will state the characteristics of the wise one later.

original: nanvevamapi vivekapratiyogipadārthānāmānantyena prātisvikarūpaiḥ sarvapadārthebhyo vivekagrahāsambhavāt kathaṃ vivekakhyātermokṣahetutvamiti
analyzed: nanu evam api viveka pratiyogi padārthānām ānantyena prātisvika rūpaiḥ sarva padārthebhyaḥ viveka graha asambhavāt katham viveka khyāteḥ mokṣa hetu tvam iti
translated: But even so, how can the realization of discrimination be the cause of liberation, since it is impossible to grasp the discrimination of all things individually due to the infinitude of the objects that are the counter-correlates of discrimination?

analyzed: ced na
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: dṛśya tva pariṇāmi tva ādi sāmānya rūpaiḥ viveka graha sambhavāt
translated: Because it is possible to grasp discrimination through general forms such as being an object of perception, being an evolute, etc.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Indeed,

original: draṣṭā svasākṣātprakāśebhyo bhinnaḥ prakāśakatvādyo yasya prakāśakaḥ sa tasmādbhinnaḥ
analyzed: draṣṭā sva sākṣāt prakāśebhyaḥ bhinnaḥ prakāśaka tvāt yaḥ yasya prakāśakaḥ sa tasmāt bhinnaḥ
translated: The seer is different from the self-luminous objects because he is the illuminator. He who is the illuminator of something is different from it.

analyzed: yathā ghaṭāt ālokaḥ vṛtti prakāśyāt ca vṛttiḥ iti anumānena ādau antar dṛśyebhyaḥ buddhi vṛtti tad ārūḍha arthebhyaḥ
translated: For example, light is different from a pot, and the manifestation is different from what is manifested through manifestation. By this inference, the seer of the internal objects first, which are manifested through the modifications of the intellect,
is established as distinct from them.

analyzed: karma kartṛ virodhaḥ ca anukūlaḥ tarkaḥ  atra ātmani vyabhicāra vāraṇāya sākṣāt padam
translated: And the contradiction between action and agent is a favorable reasoning.🔽Here, the word directly is used to avoid the fallacy of the self.

analyzed: vṛtti dvārā eva ātmanaḥ sva viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because the self is the object of its own cognition only through the modifications.

analyzed: nanu atra anumāne buddhi vṛtti mātrāt vivekaḥ sidhyatu
translated: But let the distinction be established from the mere modification of the intellect in this inference.

original: tasyā eva sākṣadātmadṛśyatvāt na prakṛtyādibhya iti cenna /
analyzed: tasyāḥ eva sākṣat ātma dṛśya tvāt na prakṛti ādibhyaḥ iti ced na
translated: Because that alone is directly the object of the self, not from primordial matter and others. If it is said that it is not so,

analyzed: vṛttīnām ajñāta sattva abhāvena hi atra anumāne lāghavāt vakṣyamāṇa tarka gaṇāt ca akhila vṛttīnām draṣṭā vibhu kūṭastha nitya eka jñāna svarūpa tayā eva sidhyati
translated: the seer of all modifications is established only as having the nature of eternal, unchanging, and single cognition, by the inference here due to the absence of the known existence of modifications and by the group of reasonings to be stated later, due to simplicity.

original: yathā naiyāyikānāṃ kṣitiḥ sakartṛkā kāryatvādityanumāne lāghavāt karturekatvanityatvādikaṃ tadvat /
analyzed: yathā naiyāyikānām kṣitiḥ sa kartṛkā kārya tvāt iti anumāne lāghavāt kartuḥ ekatva nitya tva ādikam tadvat
translated: Just as in the Nyāya inference that the earth has a maker because it is an effect, the oneness, eternality, etc. of the maker are inferred due to simplicity.

original: tatra vibhutvaṃ paricchinnabhinnatvaṃ kūṭasthatvādikatvaṃ ca pariṇāmibhinnatvādikamato
analyzed: tatra vibhu tvam paricchinna bhinna tvam kūṭastha tva ādika tvam ca pariṇāmi bhinna tva ādikam atas
translated: Of these, omnipresence is different from being limited, and being immutable, etc. is different from being mutable, etc. Therefore,

analyzed: buddhi ātmanoḥ dṛś dṛśya rūpataḥ viveka grahe sati tad uttara anumānena pariṇāmi tva apariṇāmi tva ādi rūpaiḥ
translated: when there is the discernment of the seer and the seen in the form of the intellect and the self, the discernment of the self and the non-self in the form of mutability and immutability, etc.

analyzed: sāmānyatas pi ātma anātma viveka grahaḥ ghaṭate iti
translated: is possible even in general, by inference after that.

original: ataeva pātañjale sattvapuruṣānyatākhyātireva mokṣahetutayā sthale sthale vyāsabhāṣye proktā /
analyzed: ataeva pātañjale sattva puruṣa anya tā khyātiḥ eva mokṣa hetu tayā sthale sthale vyāsa bhāṣye proktā
translated: For this very reason, in the Pātañjala [Yoga Sūtra], the knowledge of the difference between sattva and puruṣa is stated as the cause of liberation in various places in the commentary of Vyāsa.

analyzed: sattva puruṣa anya tā khyāti rūpa dṛś dṛśya viveka graha uttaram yathā ukta rītyā prakṛti ādi viveka grahāt
translated: Because after the knowledge of the difference between the seer and the seen in the form of the knowledge of the difference between sattva and puruṣa, the knowledge of the difference between prakṛti (primordial matter) and so on is possible in the manner stated.

analyzed: tatra ca sattva śabde buddhi stha tvena buddhi sattvam uktam iti
translated: And there, the word sattva is used to denote the sattva of the intellect, because it is present in the intellect.

original: evaṃ ca prakṛtyādipadārthānāṃ viśiṣyajñānābhāve 'pi tadvivekajñānaṃ ghaṭate /
analyzed: evam ca prakṛti ādi padārthānām viśiṣya jñāna abhāve tad viveka jñānam ghaṭate
translated: Thus, even in the absence of the knowledge of the objects of prakṛti (primordial matter) and so on separately, the knowledge of their difference is possible.

analyzed: etena dṛś dṛśya vivekāt avidyā nivṛttiḥ iti prācām pravādaḥ pi upapāditaḥ
translated: By this, the statement of the ancients that ignorance ceases by the discrimination of the seer and the seen is also explained.

original: kiñcātmā prakṛtitatkāryebhyo bhinno 'pariṇāmitvādityādyanumānairapi sāmānyato dṛśyaviveko draṣṭari sambhavatīti /
analyzed: kiñca ātmā prakṛti tad kāryebhyaḥ bhinnaḥ pariṇāmi tvāt ityādi anumānaiḥ api sāmānyatas dṛśya vivekaḥ draṣṭari sambhavati iti
translated: Moreover, by means of inferences such as The self is different from primordial matter and its effects because it is not subject to change, the distinction between the seer and the seen can be established in general.

original: yattvādhunikā vedāntibruvā dṛśyatvenaiva prakṛtyādīnāṃ draṣṭṛtvena ca prakṛtyādyakhilajaḍebhya ātmavivekaṃ manyante /
analyzed: yat tu ādhunikāḥ vedānti bruvāḥ dṛśya tvena eva prakṛti ādīnām draṣṭṛ tvena ca prakṛti ādi akhila jaḍebhyaḥ ātma vivekam manyante
translated: However, the modern Vedāntins consider the distinction of the self from primordial matter and so on as the seer, and from all inert matter such as primordial matter and so on, only on the basis of being the seer and being the seen.

original: ghaṭadraṣṭā ghaṭādbhinnaḥ sarvathā na ghaṭo yathā /
analyzed: ghaṭa draṣṭā ghaṭāt bhinnaḥ sarvathā na ghaṭaḥ yathā
translated: Just as the seer of a pot is in every way different from the pot, the pot is not the seer.

analyzed: deha draṣṭā tathā dehaḥ na aham ityādi rūpataḥ
translated: In the same way, the body is not the seer, because of the form I am not the body and so on.

original: tanna / ātmā vā 're draṣṭavya ityādiśrutibhirātmano 'pi dṛśyatvāt sākṣāddṛśyatvavivakṣayā ca prakṛtyāderasaṅgrahāt karaṇadvāraiva taddarśanāt
analyzed: tat na ātmā vā re draṣṭavyaḥ ityādi śrutibhiḥ ātmanaḥ api dṛśya tvāt sākṣāt dṛśya tva vivakṣayā ca prakṛti ādeḥ asaṅgrahāt karaṇa dvārā eva tad darśanāt
translated: That is not so. Because the self is also seen by scriptures such as The self is to be seen, and because primordial matter and so on are not included by the intention to speak of direct visibility, and because they are seen only through the instrument.

original: athaivaṃ kalpanīyaṃ ātmano vṛttivyāpyatvameva dṛśyatvaṃ śrutyādibhirvidhīyate na tu prakāśyatvarūpaphalavyāpyatvam /
analyzed: atha evam kalpanīyam ātmanaḥ vṛtti vyāpya tvam eva dṛśya tvam śruti ādibhiḥ vidhīyate na tu prakāśya tva rūpa phala vyāpya tvam
translated: If it is to be imagined in this way, the visibility of the self is enjoined by scriptures and so on as being pervaded by manifestation, but not as being pervaded by the fruit in the form of being illuminated.

analyzed: svayam prakāśa svarūpasya prakāśa apekṣā virahāt
translated: Because the self, which is of the nature of self-luminous, is devoid of dependence on illumination.

original: ato 'tra dṛśyatvaṃ prakāśyatvaṃ taccātmani nāstīti tadapi tuccham /
analyzed: dṛśya tvam prakāśya tvam tat ca ātmani na asti iti tat api tuccham
translated: Therefore, here visibility is being illuminated, and that does not exist in the self. So that too is futile.

original: yathā hyahamityanubhūyamāno 'pyātmā caitanyākhyaphalavyāpyo na bhavatīti bhavadbhirucyate🔽tathaiva bauddhairapīṣyate sukhaduḥkhādimattvenāpi buddhiḥ svaprakāśatayā caitanyavyāpyā na bhavatīti /
analyzed: yathā hi aham iti anubhūyamānaḥ pi ātmā caitanya ākhya phala vyāpyaḥ na bhavati iti bhavadbhiḥ ucyate  tathā eva bauddhaiḥ api iṣyate sukha duḥkha ādimattvena api buddhiḥ sva prakāśa tayā caitanya vyāpyā na bhavati iti
translated: Just as you say that the self, though experienced as I, is not pervaded by the effect called consciousness,🔽in the same way, the Buddhists also consider that cognition, even though it has the nature of pleasure, pain, etc., is not pervaded by consciousness, which is self-luminous.

original: tathā cātmanīva buddhāvapi dṛśyatvāsiddhyā dṛśyatvena rūpeṇa buddhiviveko 'tyantāpekṣito 'pi na sidhyatīti bhāṣyādiṣu cānyānyatra dūṣaṇānyuktānīti
analyzed: tathā ca ātmani iva buddhau api dṛśya tva asiddhyā dṛśya tvena rūpeṇa buddhi vivekaḥ tyanta apekṣitaḥ na sidhyati iti bhāṣya ādiṣu ca anyāni atra dūṣaṇāni uktāni iti
translated: And thus, just as in the case of the self, the distinction of cognition by its nature as the object of perception, which is absolutely necessary, is not established due to the non-establishment of perceptibility in cognition. And in the commentaries, etc., other objections are stated elsewhere.

analyzed: diś
translated: This is the direction.

analyzed: nanu sambhavati evam sāmānya rūpeṇa viveka grahaḥ
translated: But this may be so in the case of the general form of distinction.

analyzed: tathā api sāmānyāni eva bahūni santi pariṇāmi tva saṃhatyakāri tva sukha duḥkha moha ātmaka tva caturviṃśati tattva tva ādīni atas taiḥ taiḥ rūpaiḥ viveka grahāṇām
translated: Even so, there are many generalities such as transformability, acting in combination, having the nature of pleasure, pain, and delusion, having twenty-four principles, etc. Therefore, in the case of those who grasp distinction by those forms,

analyzed: mokṣa hetu tve nanugama doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: if they were the cause of liberation, there would be the fault of non-concomitance. If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: abhimāna pratibandhaka jñāna tvena eva anugamāt iti
translated: Because there is concomitance only by being the knowledge that obstructs the conceit.

original: athaivaṃ sāmānyarūpeṇa vivekasyaiva sarvābhimānanivartakatayā nāhaṃ deho nendriyāṇityādipratyekarūpairvivekagrahāṇāṃ mokṣahetutvaṃ śrutismṛtyorucyamānaṃ
analyzed: atha evam sāmānya rūpeṇa vivekasya eva sarva abhimāna nivartaka tayā na aham dehaḥ na indriyāṇi ityādi pratyeka rūpaiḥ viveka grahāṇām mokṣa hetu tvam śruti smṛtyoḥ ucyamānam
translated: Now, if discrimination itself, in its general form, is the remover of all forms of self-identification, and if the scriptures and Smritis speak of the attainment of liberation through the realization of individual forms of discrimination such as I am not the body, I am not the senses, etc.,

analyzed: katham ghaṭeta iti ced na
translated: how can this be reconciled? It is not so.

analyzed: avāntara vivekānām sāmānya viveka prapañca mātra tvāt iti
translated: Because the specific discriminations are merely elaborations of the general discrimination.

original: iti śrīvijñānabhikṣuviracite sāṅkhyasāre mokṣahetuvivekajñānasya svarūpasya paricchedaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrī vijñānabhikṣu viracite sāṅkhyasāre mokṣa hetu viveka jñānasya svarūpasya paricchedaḥ
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the nature of the discrimination-knowledge which is the cause of liberation, in the Saṅkhyasāra composed by the monk Vijñānabhiksu.

analyzed: atha tṛtīyaḥ paricchedaḥ
translated: Now begins the third chapter.

original: atha ke te prakṛtyādayo yebhyaḥ puruṣo vivecanīya ityucyate /
analyzed: atha ke te prakṛti ādayaḥ yebhyaḥ puruṣaḥ vivecanīyaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Now, who are those Prakriti and others from whom Purusha is to be discriminated? It is said:

analyzed: prakṛtiḥ buddhi ahaṅkārau tanmātra ekādaśa indriyam
translated: Prakriti, Buddhi, Ahamkara, the Tanmatras, the eleven senses,

analyzed: bhūtāni ca iti sāmānyāt caturviṃśatiḥ eva te
translated: and the elements - these twenty-four are in general.

analyzed: eteṣu eva dharma dharmya bhedena guṇa karma sāmānyānām antarbhāvaḥ
translated: Within these, the qualities, actions, and universals are included without distinction of attribute and substance.

original: tatra prakṛtitvaṃ sākṣāt paramparayā 'khilavikāropādānatvaṃ prakṛṣṭākṛtiḥ pariṇāmarūpā 'syā iti vyutpatteḥ /
analyzed: tatra prakṛti tvam sākṣāt paramparayā khila vikāra upādāna tvam prakṛṣṭa ākṛtiḥ pariṇāma rūpā syāḥ iti vyutpatteḥ
translated: Among them, Prakriti-hood is the direct and indirect cause of all modifications. The derivation is from the word Prakriti meaning having an excellent form and transformation.

original: prakṛtiḥ śaktirajā pradhānamavyaktaṃ tamo māyā 'vidyetyādayaḥ prakṛteḥ paryāyāḥ /🔽brāhmīti vidyā 'vidyeti māyeti ca tathā pare /
analyzed: prakṛtiḥ śaktiḥ ajā pradhānam avyaktam tamaḥ māyā vidyā ityādayaḥ prakṛteḥ paryāyāḥ  brāhmī iti vidyā vidyā iti māyā iti ca tathā pare
translated: Prakriti, Shakti, Aja, Pradhana, Avyakta, Tama, Maya, Avidya, etc. are synonyms of Prakriti.

analyzed: prakṛtiḥ ca parā ca iti vadanti parama ṛṣayaḥ
translated: The supreme sages say that Brahma, Vidya, Avidya, Maya, and the supreme Prakriti are synonyms.

original: iti smṛteḥ / sā ca sāmyāvasthayopalakṣitaṃ sattvādidravyatrayam /
analyzed: iti smṛteḥ sā ca sāmya avasthayā upalakṣitam sattva ādi dravya trayam
translated: This is according to the Smriti. And that (Prakriti) is the triad of substances like Sattva, etc., characterized by the state of equilibrium.

analyzed: kārya sattva ādi vāraṇāya upalakṣita antam
translated: The word upalakshita (characterized) is added to avoid the effect Sattva, etc.

analyzed: sāmya avasthā ca nyūna adhika bhāvena asaṃhanana avasthā akārya avasthā iti yāvat
translated: And the state of equilibrium is the state of non-combination due to the absence of deficiency or excess, i.e., the state of non-effect.

original: mahadādikaṃ tu kāryasattvādikaṃ na kadā 'pyakāryāvasthaṃ bhavatīti tadvyāvṛttiḥ /
analyzed: mahat ādikam tu kārya sattva ādikam na kadā pi akārya avastham bhavati iti tad vyāvṛttiḥ
translated: But the effect Sattva, etc., beginning with Mahat, never become the state of non-effect, hence the exclusion of that (state).

analyzed: vaiṣamya avasthāyām api prakṛti tva siddhaye upalakṣitam iti uktam
translated: Even in the state of inequality, it is said to be characterized in order to establish the nature of Prakriti.

analyzed: akāryam iti tu upalakṣita antasya niṣkṛṣṭa arthaḥ
translated: But the specific meaning of upalakshita (characterized) with the suffix anta (at the end) is non-effect.

analyzed: sattva ādi guṇavatī sattva ādi atiriktā prakṛtiḥ iti na śaṅkanīyam
translated: It should not be suspected that Prakriti is endowed with the qualities of Sattva, etc., and is different from Sattva, etc.

original: sattvādīnāmataddharmatvaṃ tadrūpatvāditi sāṅkhyasūtreṇa sattvādīnāṃ prakṛtisvarūpahetunā prakṛtidharmatvapratiṣedhāt /

translated: But the statement The guṇas of prakṛti should be understood like The trees of the forest.

analyzed: sattvam rajaḥ tamaḥ iti prakṛteḥ abhavan guṇāḥ
translated: Sattva, rajas, and tamas are the guṇas that arise from prakṛti.

analyzed: iti sattva ādīnām prakṛti kārya tva vacanam tu guṇa nitya tā vākya virodhena mahat tattva kāraṇī bhūta kārya sattva ādi param eva
translated: This statement that sattva, etc. are effects of prakṛti, however, refers to sattva, etc. that are the material cause of the mahat principle, in contradiction with the statement about the eternality of the guṇas.

analyzed: mahat ādi sṛṣṭiḥ hi guṇa vaiṣamyāt śrūyate
translated: For the creation of mahat, etc. is heard to be due to the inequality of the guṇas.

original: tacca vaiṣamyaṃ sajātīyasavalanena guṇāntaravyāvṛttaprakāśādiphalopahitaḥ sattvādivyavahārayogyaḥ pariṇāma iti /

translated: And that inequality is a modification that is fit to be designated as sattva, etc., being qualified by the effect of light, etc. that is distinguished from other guṇas by the association with its own kind.

analyzed: etena aṣṭāviṃśati tattva pakṣaḥ pi upapāditaḥ mantavyaḥ
translated: By this, the theory of twenty-eight principles should also be considered to be established.

analyzed: vaiṣamye eva sattva ādi vyavahāraḥ ca śrutau dṛśyate
translated: And the usage of terms like being is seen in the scriptures as referring to inequality.

original: yathā tama evedamagra āsa tatpareṇeritaṃ viṣamatvaṃ prayātyetad vai rajaso rūpaṃ khalvīritaṃ viṣamatvaṃ prayātyetad vai sattvasya rūpamiti
analyzed: yathā tamaḥ eva idam agre āsa tat pareṇa īritam viṣama tvam prayāti etat vai rajasaḥ rūpam khalu īritam viṣama tvam prayāti etat vai sattvasya rūpam iti
translated: This world was indeed in darkness in the beginning. It proceeds to inequality, being impelled by that. This is indeed the form of rajas. It proceeds to inequality, being impelled by that. This is indeed the form of sattva.

analyzed: sattva ādi trayam ca sukha prakāśa lāghava prasāda ādi guṇavat tayā
translated: And the three, sattva etc., should be seen as having the qualities of happiness, light, lightness, clarity etc.,

original: saṃyogavibhāgādimattayā 'nāśritatvopādānatvādinā ca draṣṭavye 'pi puruṣopakaraṇatvāt puruṣabandhakatvācca guṇaśabdenocyate /
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāga ādimattayā na āśrita tva upādāna tva ādinā ca draṣṭavye pi puruṣa upakaraṇa tvāt puruṣa bandhaka tvāt ca guṇa śabdena ucyate
translated: as having conjunction, disjunction etc., as not being dependent, as being the material cause etc., but are called guṇas because they are the instruments of the soul and because they bind the soul.

analyzed: indriya ādi vat
translated: Like the sense faculties etc.

analyzed: guṇānām sukha duḥkha moha ātmaka tva pravādaḥ tu dharma dharmya bhedāt
translated: But the statement that the guṇas have the nature of happiness, pain, and delusion is due to the non-difference of the quality and the qualified.

analyzed: manasaḥ saṅkalpa ātmaka tva vat
translated: Like the mind having the nature of volition.

analyzed: tatra sattvam sukha prasāda prakāśa ādi aneka dharmakam prādhānyataḥ tu sukha ātmakam ucyate
translated: Among them, sattva has many qualities such as happiness, clarity, light etc., but is primarily said to have the nature of happiness.

analyzed: evam rajaḥ pi duḥkha kāluṣya pravṛtti ādi aneka dharmakam prādhānyataḥ tu duḥkha ātmakam ucyate
translated: Similarly, rajas also has many qualities such as pain, impurity, activity etc., but is primarily said to have the nature of pain.

analyzed: tathā tamaḥ pi moha āvaraṇa stambhana ādi aneka dharmakam prādhānyataḥ tu moha ātmakam ucyate
translated: Similarly, darkness, which is the obstruction of delusion, is said to have many properties such as stupefaction, but primarily it is of the nature of delusion.

analyzed: te eva dharmāḥ teṣām lakṣaṇāni bhavanti
translated: Those very properties are the characteristics of those [gunas].

analyzed: sattva ādi sañjñā ca anvarthā
translated: And the names sattva, etc. are meaningful.

original: sato bhāvaḥ sattvamuttamatvamiti vyutpattyā hi dharmaprādhānyenottamaṃ puruṣopakaraṇaṃ sattvaśabdārthaḥ /

translated: For by the derivation the state of being existent is sattva, the state of being supreme is sattva, the meaning of the word sattva is the supreme instrument of the person, primarily as a property.

analyzed: madhyamam ca rajaḥ śabda arthaḥ rāga yogāt

analyzed: adhamam ca tamaḥ śabda arthaḥ

analyzed: adharma āvaraṇa yogāt
translated: Because of its connection with the obstruction of adharma.

analyzed: tāni ca sattva ādīni pratyekam asaṅkhya vyaktayaḥ
translated: And those sattva, etc. each have innumerable individual instances.

analyzed: laghu tva ādi dharmaiḥ anyonya sādharmyam vaidharmyam ca guṇānām iti sāṅkhyasūtrāt
translated: Because of the properties such as lightness, etc., there is mutual similarity and dissimilarity of the gunas, according to the Sāṅkhya aphorism.

translated: For in this aphorism, the similarity of many sattvas is by lightness, etc., and the dissimilarity of rajas and tamas is by that same [lightness, etc.].

original: evaṃ calatvādinā gurutvādinā ca bahūnāṃ rajasāṃ bahūnāṃ ca tamasāṃ tadubhayamuktamiti /
analyzed: evam calatva ādinā gurutva ādinā ca bahūnām rajasām bahūnām ca tamasām tat ubhayam uktam iti
translated: Thus, the same is said of many rajas and many tamas by mobility, etc. and heaviness, etc.

analyzed: ekadā aneka brahmāṇḍa ādi sṛṣṭi śravaṇāt

analyzed: tathā ca kāryāṇām ananta vaicitryam na ghaṭate

analyzed: na ca saṃyoga vaicitryāt vaicitryam syāt iti vācyam

analyzed: vibhūnām trayāṇām guṇānām svatas saṃyoga vaicitrya asambhavāt
translated: Because for the three all-pervading qualities, the variety of conjunctions is not possible by themselves.

analyzed: dravya antarasya ca avacchedakībhūtasya abhāvāt iti
translated: And because there is no other substance that could serve as a limiting adjunct.

analyzed: tasmāt sattva ādīni asaṅkhya vyaktikāni eva dravyāṇi
translated: Therefore, sattva etc. are substances with innumerable individualities.

analyzed: tāni ca sattva ādīni yathāyogyam aṇu vibhu parimāṇakāni
translated: And those sattva etc. have atomic and all-pervading dimensions as appropriate.

analyzed: anyathā rajasaḥ cala svabhāva tva vacana virodhāt  ākāśa kāraṇa tvasya ca vibhu tva aucityāt
translated: Otherwise, it would contradict the statement that rajas has a fluctuating nature.🔽And because it is appropriate that space is all-pervading, being the cause.

analyzed: sarveṣām kāraṇa dravyāṇām vibhu tve kāryāṇām paricchinna tva anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because if all the causal substances are all-pervading, the limitation of effects would be impossible.

analyzed: nanu evam vaiśeṣika uktāni eva pārthiva aṇu ādīni prakṛtiḥ iti āya ayam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that in that case the atomic earth particles etc. mentioned by the Vaiśeṣikas are the prakriti, that is not so.

analyzed: gandha ādi guṇa śūnya tvena kāraṇa dravyeṣu smākam viśeṣāt

analyzed: tat uktam viṣṇu purāṇa ādiṣu
translated: That is stated in the Viṣṇu Purāṇa etc.

analyzed: avyaktam kāraṇam yat tat pradhānam ṛṣi sattamaiḥ
translated: That unmanifest cause is called pradhāna by the best sages.

analyzed: procyate prakṛtiḥ sūkṣmā nityam sat asat ātmakam
translated: It is said to be subtle prakriti, eternal, and of the nature of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: śabda sparśa vihīnam tad rūpa ādibhiḥ asaṃyutam
translated: It is devoid of sound and touch, and is not associated with form etc.

analyzed: triguṇam tat jagat yoniḥ anādi prabhava apyayam
translated: It is of three guṇas, the source of the world, without beginning, and the cause of origin and dissolution.

analyzed: ityādinā
translated: Thus it is stated.

analyzed: vaiśeṣikāṇām kāraṇa dravyeṣu gandha ādi anumānam tu bhāṣye smābhiḥ nirākṛtam
translated: As for the inference of smell etc. in the causal substances by the Vaiśeṣikas, it has been refuted by us in the Bhāṣya.

analyzed: atha evam api prakṛteḥ aṇu vibhu sādhāraṇa sattva ādi aneka vyakti rupatve paricchinna tva ekatva akriyatva siddhānta kṣatiḥ iti mā evam
translated: Even so, there is damage to the conclusion that prakriti has many manifestations like atoms, omnipresence, sattva etc., due to its being unconfined, one, and inactive. That is not so.

analyzed: kāraṇa dravya tva rūpa prakṛti tvena eva aparicchinna tva vacanāt
translated: Because unconfinedness is stated only by the nature of being prakriti, which is the nature of the causal substance.

analyzed: gandha tvena gandhānām pṛthivī vyāpaka tā vat
translated: Just as smells are all-pervading in earth by virtue of being smells.

analyzed: ākāśa ādi prakṛtīnām vibhu tvena eva prakṛti vibhu tva siddhānta upapatteḥ ca

translated: Similarly, because the absence of difference due to the difference of souls and the difference of creations is the meaning of the word 'one'.

analyzed: ajām ekām iti śrutitaḥ tathā vagamāt

analyzed: anyathā śruti smṛtiṣu uktasya prakṛti kṣobhasya anupapatteḥ iti
translated: Otherwise, the agitation of the primordial matter mentioned in the Vedic texts and Smritis would be impossible.
